titleScreen.titleScreenIntroduction:
Welcome to Peking's Kaoya Island! 🦆✨🏝️
Join the duck as it travels through the island of Artificial Intelligence. From the depths of Big Data to the wonders of Connectionist AI and beyond.
Each stop along the path reveals new challenges, interactive games, and knowledge to power up your neural network.

Are you ready to learn, explore, and level up your AI smarts?
Let’s begin the journey! 🚀

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: RDBMS can store more than just numerical data, they can handle text and other structured formats too.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: RDBMS can store more than just numerical data, they can handle text and other structured formats too.

answers.text: They can only store numerical data in columns and rows.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Big Data exceeds the capacity of traditional databases because of the 3Vs, Volume, Velocity, and Variety. Traditional systems weren’t built for massive, fast, and unstructured data.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Big Data exceeds the capacity of traditional databases because of the 3Vs, Volume, Velocity, and Variety. Traditional systems weren’t built for massive, fast, and unstructured data.

answers.text: They are not designed to manage data with high volume, velocity, and variety.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Cloud storage is a separate infrastructure issue; not all RDBMS are limited to on-premise systems.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Cloud storage is a separate infrastructure issue; not all RDBMS are limited to on-premise systems.

answers.text: They cannot store data in the cloud.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Cloud storage is a separate infrastructure issue; not all RDBMS are limited to on-premise systems.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: RDBMS can perform analytics, but they struggle at Big Data scale.

answers.text: They cannot be used for analytics tasks.

params.question: Which of the following best explains why traditional RDBMS tools struggle to handle Big Data?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Large data doesn’t automatically equal useful data.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Large data doesn’t automatically equal useful data.

answers.text: Because all large data automatically has business value.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Value refers to usefulness, not cost.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Value refers to usefulness, not cost.

answers.text: Because it refers to the monetary cost of storing data.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The Value dimension emphasizes that data by itself is not useful, it becomes valuable only when analyzed for insight or decision-making.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The Value dimension emphasizes that data by itself is not useful, it becomes valuable only when analyzed for insight or decision-making.

answers.text: Because data is only valuable when it provides meaningful insights.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Processing speed relates to Velocity, not Value.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Processing speed relates to Velocity, not Value.

answers.text: Because value measures how fast the data can be processed.

params.question: Why is “Value” considered one of the 5Vs of Big Data?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: This is reversed, MapReduce relies on disk I/O, while Spark runs in memory.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: This is reversed, MapReduce relies on disk I/O, while Spark runs in memory.

answers.text: Spark uses disk-based processing, while MapReduce runs entirely in memory.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Spark’s in-memory computation allows it to process data up to 100x faster than disk-based MapReduce.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Spark’s in-memory computation allows it to process data up to 100x faster than disk-based MapReduce.

answers.text: Spark processes data in memory, reducing the need for repeated disk access.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Spark handles both structured and unstructured data.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Spark handles both structured and unstructured data.

answers.text: Spark can only process structured data, making it faster.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Spark actually supports both batch and real-time processing, unlike traditional MapReduce.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Spark actually supports both batch and real-time processing, unlike traditional MapReduce.

answers.text: MapReduce supports real-time streaming, while Spark does not.

tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Hive is for batch analytics, not real-time streaming (that’s Kafka or Flink).

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Tableau turns raw data into interactive charts and dashboards for decision-making.

params.textField: Big Data refers to massive and complex datasets that traditional *RDBMS:What type of system struggles with massive data?* tools cannot handle. It is defined by five key characteristics known as the 5Vs: *Volume:Which V measures data size?*, *Velocity:Which V measures data speed?*, *Variety:Which V means different data types?*, *Veracity:Which V ensures accuracy?*, and *Value:Which V means usefulness of data?*. The *Relational:Which model introduced tables and SQL?* database model was created by *Codd* and became the foundation for modern data systems. Later, Big Data technologies like *Hadoop:Which framework processes data across clusters?* and *AWS S3:Which cloud service stores massive data?* introduced distributed:What type of storage splits data across servers?* storage, allowing organizations to manage data on a global scale.

params.textField: Big Data technologies are grouped into *storage:Which category includes Hadoop and NoSQL?*, *processing:Which includes Spark and Flink?*, *analytics:Which helps find insights?*, *visualization:Which turns data into charts and dashboards?*, and *security:Which protects sensitive information?*. For storage, *HDFS:Which system stores data in blocks across machines?* is used in the Hadoop ecosystem. *In processing, Spark:Which tool is faster than MapReduce?* performs in-memory processing, while *Kafka:Which tool handles real-time streaming?* manages continuous data flow. Analytical tools like *Hive:Which tool lets you query data with SQL-like commands?* and *Presto:Which tool performs fast distributed queries?* are often paired with visualization tools such as *Tableau:Which tool helps visualize results?* and *Power BI:Which Microsoft tool creates interactive dashboards?*. To maintain safety, *Ranger:Which tool manages data access control?* and *IAM:Which AWS service controls permissions?* ensure strong security and governance across platforms.

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: Aggregation means combining or summarizing multiple data values into a single value, such as calculating totals, averages, or counts. Converting units or scales (like changing currencies to USD) is called normalization or standardization, not aggregation.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Aggregation means combining or summarizing multiple data values into a single value, such as calculating totals, averages, or counts. Converting units or scales (like changing currencies to USD) is called normalization or standardization, not aggregation.

questions:
The four main steps of the data processing cycle are Collection, Cleaning, Transformation, and *loading*.

Normalization adjusts the *range* or scale of data to make values comparable.

Stream processing handles data in *real time* as it arrives.

ETL stands for Extract, Transform, and *load*.

words.clue: Removing names to protect patient identity
Method adding noise to preserve privacy
Founder of the Medallion Fund using data to trade
Devices collecting temperature and vibration data
Query tool for processing large datasets
Replacing identifiers with random values

Biased training set problem in hiring AI

Lawful agreement users give before data collection.
Oracle’s process for syncing data between systems.
2017 incident where millions of people’s data were leaked.
Government action that enforces data protection laws.
Large-scale data storage area used to integrate multiple sources.
AI-powered trading method based on massive datasets.
Principle requiring companies to take responsibility for data misuse.

tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Connectionist AI learns by learning from patterns in data instead of following fixed rules.

answers.text: It uses fixed logic rules to make decisions

params.question: What is the main idea behind Connectionist AI?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Netflix’s recommendation system is not Symbolic AI because it doesn’t rely on fixed rules or logic statements. Instead, it uses Connectionist AI (neural networks) that learn patterns from user data automatically. Symbolic AI would require manually coded “if-then” rules.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Netflix’s recommendation system is not Symbolic AI because it doesn’t rely on fixed rules or logic statements. Instead, it uses Connectionist AI (neural networks) that learn patterns from user data automatically. Symbolic AI would require manually coded “if-then” rules.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Netflix’s system is data-driven, not rule-based. It uses Connectionist AI to analyze millions of viewing habits and predict what each user is likely to enjoy next.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Netflix’s system is data-driven, not rule-based. It uses Connectionist AI to analyze millions of viewing habits and predict what each user is likely to enjoy next.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Netflix’s system uses Connectionist AI to analyze millions of viewing habits and predict what each user is likely to enjoy next.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Netflix’s system is uses Connectionist AI to analyze millions of viewing habits and predict what each user is likely to enjoy next.

answers.text: A connectionist AI that learns from user behavior patterns

params.question: Who created the first mathematical model of an artificial neuron?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts model was a mathematical and logical abstraction, not a biological one.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts model was a mathematical and logical abstraction, not a biological one.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts neuron was a simplified brain model — it outputs 1 or 0 depending on whether the total input passes a set threshold, showing how logic can emerge from networks of neurons.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts neuron was a simplified brain model — it outputs 1 or 0 depending on whether the total input passes a set threshold, showing how logic can emerge from networks of neurons.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: the McCulloch-Pitts model was a simplified, digital model of the brain, not one that dealt with continuous or analog variations like real biological neurons do.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: the McCulloch-Pitts model was a simplified, digital model of the brain, not one that dealt with continuous or analog variations like real biological neurons do.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts model was deterministic, not random. Each neuron’s output depended strictly on whether its inputs crossed a threshold. There was no randomness involved. The model focused on logical computation, not probability or chance.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts model was deterministic, not random. Each neuron’s output depended strictly on whether its inputs crossed a threshold. There was no randomness involved. The model focused on logical computation, not probability or chance.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts neuron was a simplified brain model. It outputs 1 or 0 depending on whether the total input passes a set threshold, showing how logic can emerge from networks of neurons.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The McCulloch-Pitts neuron was a simplified brain model. It outputs 1 or 0 depending on whether the total input passes a set threshold, showing how logic can emerge from networks of neurons.

params.question: The McCulloch-Pitts model represented neurons as:

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Its major innovation was that it could learn automatically by adjusting connection weights based on training data. Unlike symbolic or rule-based systems, the Perceptron learned from examples, making it an early form of machine learning.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Its major innovation was that it could learn automatically by adjusting connection weights based on training data. Unlike symbolic or rule-based systems, the Perceptron learned from examples, making it an early form of machine learning.

answers.text: It could be programmed using logic rules

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Rosenblatt’s Perceptron was the first neural network that could learn through experience, updating its weights based on errors — a key step toward modern machine learning.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Rosenblatt’s Perceptron was the first neural network that could learn through experience, updating its weights based on errors — a key step toward modern machine learning.

answers.text: It learned from examples by adjusting connections

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The Perceptron was not designed to mimic feelings or emotions. Its innovation was learning from data. The focus was on pattern recognition and learning, not emotional simulation.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The Perceptron was not designed to mimic feelings or emotions. Its innovation was learning from data. The focus was on pattern recognition and learning, not emotional simulation.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: The Perceptron was not built to play games or make strategic decisions. Its true innovation was that it could learn patterns from data by adjusting connection weights — it was a learning machine, not a programmed chess-playing system.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The Perceptron was not built to play games or make strategic decisions. Its true innovation was that it could learn patterns from data by adjusting connection weights — it was a learning machine, not a programmed chess-playing system.

tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: The true goal of learning isn’t just memorizing data — it’s understanding patterns so the network can apply what it learned to unseen examples, just like humans do.

params.question: What is the main goal of a neural network’s learning process?

words.clue: The smallest computational unit in a neural network.
Numerical value that determines the importance of an input.
Constant that shifts the neuron’s output even when inputs are zero.
Function that introduces non-linearity to help the model learn complex patterns.
The first layer where data enters the network.
Layers where most computation and pattern extraction happen.
The layer that produces the final prediction or classification.
The process of sending data forward through the network to make predictions.
Algorithm that adjusts weights to reduce prediction error.
Mathematical process used to minimize the loss by updating weights.
Type of learning where the model trains on labeled examples.
Learning method where the network discovers structure without labels.
AI approach where an agent learns through trial, error, and rewards.
When a model performs well on training data but poorly on new data.
Technique like dropout or early stopping that helps prevent overfitting
Simplest neural network where information moves only forward.
Type of network designed to process images and spatial data.
Layer in a CNN that reduces image size and prevents overfitting.
Neural network specialized for sequential data such as text or speech.
Architecture that uses self-attention to process input in parallel.

questions: Warren *McCulloch/mcculloh/Mcculloh/mcCulloh/MCCULLOH* and Walter Pitts created the first mathematical model of a neuron in 1943.
The rule “neurons that fire together, wire together” was introduced by *Donald/donald/DONALD* Hebb.
The 2012 deep learning model that revolutionized image recognition on ImageNet was called *AlexNet/alexnet/Alexnet/alexNet/ALEXNET*.
The ability of neural networks to apply learned patterns to new, unseen data is called *Generalization/generalization/GENERALIZATION*.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Gradient Boosting is a decision tree–based ensemble method, not used for neural networks.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Gradient Boosting is a decision tree–based ensemble method, not used for neural networks.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Reinforcement learning involves rewards and penalties, but it doesn’t train multi-layer neural networks.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Reinforcement learning involves rewards and penalties, but it doesn’t train multi-layer neural networks.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Backpropagation, popularized by Rumelhart, Hinton, and Williams, enabled efficient training of multi-layer networks.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Backpropagation, popularized by Rumelhart, Hinton, and Williams, enabled efficient training of multi-layer networks.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Hebbian learning is older (1949) and only explains how neuron connections strengthen; it can’t train deep layers.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Hebbian learning is older (1949) and only explains how neuron connections strengthen; it can’t train deep layers.

params.question: Which algorithm was rediscovered in 1986 and allowed the training of multi-layer neural networks?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Symbolic AI does not learn from data, it relies on predefined logical rules.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Symbolic AI does not learn from data, it relies on predefined logical rules.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Symbol manipulation is the hallmark of Symbolic AI, not Connectionist AI.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Symbol manipulation is the hallmark of Symbolic AI, not Connectionist AI.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Symbolic AI is rule-based, while Connectionist AI automatically discovers patterns through data.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Symbolic AI is rule-based, while Connectionist AI automatically discovers patterns through data.

answers.text: Symbolic AI uses explicit rules; Connectionist AI learns patterns

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Connectionist AI excels with unstructured data like text, images, and sound.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Connectionist AI excels with unstructured data like text, images, and sound.

params.question: What is the main difference between Symbolic AI and Connectionist AI?

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Almost, but not quite. While some smaller models can be partially interpreted, large neural networks are generally difficult to explain, not highly interpretable.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Almost, but not quite. While some smaller models can be partially interpreted, large neural networks are generally difficult to explain, not highly interpretable.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Close! Overfitting is a related issue, but it’s more of a training challenge than a fundamental weakness. The deeper problem is that these models lack clear interpretability.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Close! Overfitting is a related issue, but it’s more of a training challenge than a fundamental weakness. The deeper problem is that these models lack clear interpretability.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Neural networks often function as “black boxes,” making it difficult to understand how they arrive at a given output.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Neural networks often function as “black boxes,” making it difficult to understand how they arrive at a given output.

tipsAndFeedback.chosenFeedback: Plausible but wrong. Connectionist AI actually excels at messy and unstructured data like speech, text, and images.
tipsAndFeedback.notChosenFeedback: Plausible but wrong. Connectionist AI actually excels at messy and unstructured data like speech, text, and images.

answers.text: Limited ability to handle noisy or unstructured data

params.question: Which of the following best describes Pattern Recognition in AI?

words.clue: The large public image dataset with over 12 million labeled images used to train deep vision models.
The architecture behind models like GPT and BERT that use self-attention to process language.
A neural network inspired by how humans perceive visual patterns, used in image recognition.
A type of neural network that models relationships and connections, often used for fraud detection.
A type of neural network used for sequential data like text or transactions over time.
The process of turning words into numerical representations that capture meaning.
The method transformers use to weigh relationships between words.
Ensuring that AI treats everyone fairly and without discrimination.
Protecting personal information through encryption or anonymization.
The process of ensuring AI systems remain fair, transparent, and responsible.
The IBM AI tool criticized for giving unsafe medical advice due to training flaws.
The idea that developers or companies must take responsibility for the outcomes of their AI systems
The 2024 incident involving fake political videos generated by AI.
The result when AI decisions are too complex to interpret.
OpenAI’s model family capable of generating human-like text.
The process of narrowing millions of items to a few hundred candidates
The layer of a CNN that detects simple features like edges.
The streaming giant that personalizes content using AI.
The global payment platform using AI to detect fraud.
